Description: Lower body sherd of Chian black-figured Sphinx and Lion Style pottery stemmed bowl; cream slip; interior: black-figure decoration consisting of parts of two lions seated to right (only front paw of first, haunch and hind legs of second lion, with added red on haunch); incised full rosette with added red centre and part of rising rosette as filling ornament; below, frieze of dots between pairs of lines; at turn to stem, part of tongue frieze; exterior: three black bands, the third above junction with stem.
Curator's comments: Object owned and held by the Royal Museum of Art and History, Brussels. This record is included in the British Museum database as part of the Museum’s Naukratis Project, a research collaboration that aims to virtually re-unite finds from the ancient port city of Naukratis, now distributed over 80 museums worldwide.

Lemos places this sherd in Group A of the Sphinx and Lion Style. The decoration on the vases from this group is the most elaborate. The rosette has a standard cogwheel shape, the figures are carefully drawn and details are expertly incised.
Bibliographic references: CVA Brussels III / Corpus Vasorum Antiquorum Belgique (p. 2, pl. 3, no. 4)
Lemos 1991 / Archaic Pottery of Chios. The Decorated Styles (p. 147, p. 319, no. 1413, pl. 181) (The image is reversed)
Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (GD.2101) (phase 2)
Previous owner: Currently owned by: Musées Royaux d’Art et d’Histoire, Brussels
Acquisition notes: Donated to the museum by the Egypt Exploration Fund
